title: Jehoshaphat and Ahab's Alliance
shortSummary: This chapter recounts the alliance between Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, and Ahab, king of Israel, as they prepare to battle at Ramothgilead. It highlights the contrast between false prophets who assure victory and the true prophet Micaiah who reveals God's sovereign judgment. The chapter ends with Ahab's death, fulfilling the prophecy of divine judgment.
timeline: c. 850 BC - Reign of Jehoshaphat and Ahab

keyCharacters.name: Jehoshaphat
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah known for his faithfulness, who allies with Ahab and seeks God's guidance before battle.

keyCharacters.name: Ahab
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel, known for his wickedness, who persuades Jehoshaphat to join him in battle and rejects true prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Micaiah son of Imla
keyCharacters.description: The true prophet of the LORD who delivers God's warning of defeat and judgment against Ahab.

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah son of Chenaanah
keyCharacters.description: A false prophet who deceives the kings by prophesying victory and physically attacks Micaiah.

definitions.definition: A close relationship or alliance, often by marriage or political agreement, as seen between Jehoshaphat and Ahab.
A messenger chosen by God to deliver His word, whether of warning, instruction, or encouragement.
A city east of the Jordan River, significant as a strategic military site contested between Israel and Syria.
A spirit permitted by God to deceive false prophets, illustrating God's sovereign use of even evil to accomplish His purposes.

outline.heading: Alliance Between Jehoshaphat and Ahab
outline.description: Jehoshaphat and Ahab form a political and military alliance, with Ahab inviting Jehoshaphat to join him in battle at Ramothgilead. They seek prophetic counsel, and the majority of prophets predict success.

outline.heading: Request for a True Prophet
outline.description: Jehoshaphat insists on consulting a prophet of the LORD, leading to the summoning of Micaiah, who initially gives a favorable answer but then reveals a divine vision of Israel's defeat.

outline.heading: Micaiah’s Vision and Prophecy
outline.description: Micaiah describes a heavenly council where a lying spirit is sent to deceive Ahab’s prophets, exposing the false assurances and foretelling Ahab’s downfall.

outline.heading: Rejection and Imprisonment of Micaiah
outline.description: Despite Micaiah’s truthful prophecy, Ahab orders him imprisoned and fed with affliction, showing the king’s rejection of God’s warning.

outline.heading: The Battle and Ahab’s Death
outline.description: Jehoshaphat and Ahab go to battle; Ahab disguises himself but is fatally wounded by a random arrow, fulfilling Micaiah’s prophecy.

application: Seek God’s guidance earnestly in all decisions, especially in matters of conflict or alliance.
Discern carefully between true and false prophetic voices by testing their words against Scripture and God’s revealed truth.
Trust in God’s sovereign plan even when circumstances appear favorable or when others assure success.
Be willing to stand for God’s truth, even if it results in opposition or suffering, as Micaiah exemplifies.

keyVerses.text: And Jehoshaphat said unto the king of Israel, Enquire, I pray thee, at the word of the LORD to day.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the importance of seeking God’s direct guidance before making decisions.

keyVerses.text: Then he said, I did see all Israel scattered upon the mountains, as sheep that have no shepherd: and the LORD said, These have no master; let them return therefore every man to his house in peace.
keyVerses.significance: Micaiah’s vision reveals the true spiritual condition of Israel and the impending judgment.

keyVerses.text: And he said, I will go out, and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets. And the LORD said, Thou shalt entice him, and thou shalt also prevail: go out, and do even so.
keyVerses.significance: Shows God’s sovereign control over even deception to accomplish His righteous purposes.

keyVerses.text: And the battle increased that day: howbeit the king of Israel stayed himself up in his chariot against the Syrians until the even: and about the time of the sun going down he died.
keyVerses.significance: The fulfillment of prophecy demonstrating God’s faithfulness to His word and judgment on disobedience.
